image.altText: A woman with brown short hair sits behind a microphone

items.synopsis: The senior bureaucrat who oversaw the rollout of the Robodebt scheme is suspended without pay after the royal commission found she did "nothing of substance" after discovering illegalities.

title.children: Kathryn Campbell suspended from $900K job after damning Robodebt findings

image.altText: fdlunz_AucklandShootingStills_2007_00-01-40.18-2

items.synopsis: New Zealand police say the 24-year-old gunman, who shot two people dead in World Cup host city Auckland, has previously worked at the construction site where the incident took place. Follow live.

title.children: Auckland gunman barricaded himself inside elevator shaft before firing at police

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're just joining the blog, here's what we know about the tragedy that unfolded in Auckland this morning: Three people, including a 24-year-old gunman have died after he entered a building under construction in the Auckland CBD and opened fire Six other people, including a police officer are being treated for injuries varying from moderate to serious Police believe the gunman was an employee at the construction site The gunman did not have a gun licence and was on a house arrest order with an exemption to work at the site The two victims were found dead by police in the bottom of the building The shooter was found dead a short time after he barricaded himself in an elevator shaft and shot at police A small area of the CBD is still cordoned off as investigations continue Teams in the FIFA Womens World Cup were staying nearby ahead of the first match in Auckland this evening The tournament will still go ahead and police say there is no threat to the public
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Here's what we know

children.content: If you're just joining the blog, here's what we know about the tragedy that unfolded in Auckland
this morning:
Three people, including a 24-year-old gunman have died after he entered a building under construction in the Auckland CBD and opened fire
Six other people, including a police officer are being treated for injuries varying from moderate to serious
Police believe the gunman was an employee at the construction site
The gunman did not have a gun licence and was on a house arrest order with an exemption to work at the site
The two victims were found dead by police in the bottom of the building
The shooter was found dead a short time after he barricaded himself in an elevator shaft and shot at police
A small area of the CBD is still cordoned off as investigations continue
Teams in the FIFA Womens World Cup were staying nearby ahead of the first match in Auckland this evening
The tournament will still go ahead and police say there is no threat to the public

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Commissioner Andrew Coster confirmed the shooter was the subject of a sentence of home detention but had an exemption to work at the site where the incident happened. "The individual is known for primarily family violence history," he said. "There is nothing to suggest that he has a higher level of risk than was indicated by that history." He said the motivation for the attack was not clear. "There are some indications of mental health history but I don't have the details," he said. "We believe the weapon is a shotgun, so not prohibited, however the individual does not have a firearms licence so he should not have possessed that."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shooter was on home detention orders

props.alt: A man in a police suit uniform in front of a police background

children.content: New Zealand Police Commissioner Andrew Coster
(ABC News)
Commissioner Andrew Coster confirmed the shooter was the subject of a sentence of home detention but had an exemption to work at the site where the incident happened.
"The individual is known for primarily family violence history," he said.
"There is nothing to suggest that he has a higher level of risk than was indicated by that history."
He said the motivation for the attack was not clear.
"There are some indications of mental health history but I don't have the details," he said.
"We believe the weapon is a shotgun, so not prohibited, however the individual does not have a firearms licence so he should not have possessed that."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand Police say they believe the offender is a 24-year-old who worked at the construction site where the shooting took place. Addressing the media, Police Commissioner Andrew Coster said the gunman made his way up through the site firing multiple shots. "At around 8am our armed offenders squad supported by the special tactics group located the offender inside a lift shaft where he had barricaded himself and attempted to engage him, having secured the floors above and below," he said, "The offender fired at police and injured an officer. Shots were exchanged and the offender was later found deceased." Police arrived within 10 minutes and found two members of the public dead in the lower levels of the building. "We know that several workers found refuge hiding inside the building during the event," he said. The injured police officer was transported to hospital in a critical condition and is now stable.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gunman barricaded himself inside elevator shaft

children.content: New Zealand Police say they believe the offender is a 24-year-old who worked at the construction site where the shooting took place.
Addressing the media, Police Commissioner Andrew Coster said the gunman made his way up through the site firing multiple shots.

"At around 8am our armed offenders squad supported by the special tactics group located the offender inside a lift shaft where he had barricaded himself and attempted to engage him, having secured the floors above and below," he said,
"The offender fired at police and injured an officer. Shots were exchanged and the offender was later found deceased."
Police arrived within 10 minutes and found two members of the public dead in the lower levels of the building.
"We know that several workers found refuge hiding inside the building during the event," he said.
The injured police officer was transported to hospital in a critical condition and is now stable.

image.altText: The Queensland Police Service insignia on the sleeve of a shirt.

items.synopsis: The offences are alleged to have been committed on the Gold Coast between 1995 and 2002, when the man, now 75, was a serving officer.

title.children: Former Queensland police officer charged with almost 70 child abuse offences

image.altText: Aerial view of a tank on a semi-trailer next to the burnt shell of a B-double truck.

items.synopsis: One lane has reopened on the Bruce Highway this morning as investigators piece together the chain of events that led to a crash involving several caravans, large trucks and a US military tank.

title.children: Police 'flabbergasted' no lives lost in fiery crash involving US tank as highway partially reopens

image.altText: A woman wearing a red scarf looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Maria Barclay was just 17 years old when she enlisted in the Australian Defence Force and has told the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide serving among very few women in the military has had traumatising consequences.

title.children: 'I didn't have a voice': Ex-servicewoman tells commission of feeling isolated after sexual assault

image.altText: A police officer stands in front of a police car.

items.synopsis: New Zealand police say the 24-year-old had no licence for the shotgun he used to carry out the attack, and that he had a history of family violence.

title.children: Man who killed two at Auckland construction site had no gun licence, NZ police confirm

image.altText: A middle-aged white woman with short grey hair. She is standing by a door, wearing a blue sweater

items.synopsis: Jenny Moncur's husband Royce died in 2014 after being diagnosed with cancer. Almost a decade later, she was still being contacted about his Telstra account.

title.children: 'Like a Monty Python skit': Telstra 'harassed' Jenny for nine years over her dead husband's account

image.altText: Composite image of Daniel Andrews and Kereyn Smith.

items.synopsis: Commonwealth Games Federation vice-president Kereyn Smith questions Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews's integrity over his decision to axe the 2026 Games.

title.children: 'Unprecedented': Games VP challenges Daniel Andrews's version of events on cancellation

image.altText: Two dingoes on the beach at Fraser Island, with one wearing a GPS tracking collar.

items.synopsis: One of the dingoes involved in the attack of a young woman on K'gari earlier this week has been destroyed. The animal was also responsible for the hospitalisation of a six-year-old girl in April.

title.children: Rangers 'humanely euthanase' dingo responsible for attacks on K'gari (Fraser Island)

image.altText: a woman and a man with an assistance dog sitting on a silver bench at a train station, smiling and talking to each other

items.synopsis: In preparation for Cross River Rail, a warehouse has been transformed into a mock underground station – fitted out with replica platform doors, a foyer and even a mural of a train to ensure everyone can access Brisbane's new transport links.

title.children: Brisbane's Cross River Rail is costing billions. Meet the people making sure everyone can safely use it

image.altText: An Australian female road cyclists stands with the national flag behind her while wearing her Comm Games gold medal.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has rejected suggestions by Victoria's opposition leader that the federal government did not allocate money for the Commonwealth Games in the last budget because they knew they were going to be cancelled.

title.children: Federal government did not get pre-budget warning of games cancellation, Albanese says

image.altText: Andre Viljoen in his homemade jet flying above Tuross Head

items.synopsis: It started with model aeroplanes as a teenager. Then he piloted gliders. Now, retired dentist Andre Viljoen has built his own jet aircraft to see Australia's best sights.

title.children: Retiree's bird's-eye view of Australia from his homemade jet aircraft

image.altText: Copy of Shadows

items.synopsis: Women's football started with sell-out crowds in the 1920s, only to be banned a year later. Through five decades of darkness, football's pioneers carried the torch for future generations.

title.children: Out of the shadows: How women's football flourished after 50 years of darkness

image.altText: Marnus Labuschagne holds the bridge of his nose in frustration while walking off the field

items.synopsis: Predicted rain means this critical fourth Ashes Test could be compressed into three days' worth of play, only adding to the frustration of Australia's batting performance on day one.

title.children: Australia can't close the door on England as Ashes remain alive in Test forced into fast-forward

image.altText: A glowing sign with the letters AI at a conference.

items.synopsis: Internet users are bypassing China's great firewall to connect with a US-made chatbot, as Beijing releases rules paving the way for the country's generative AI boom.

title.children: 'Magic': Tutorials show people in China how to evade censors and connect to ChatGPT

image.altText: A group of army personnel walk away from two white army helicopters in the middle of a field

items.synopsis: Germany's army chief says his country wants to send a message it is interested in what is going on in the Indo-Pacific region as his troops take part in a major military exercise for the first time.

title.children: Tent cities across north Queensland as 30,000 troops begin Australia's largest war games

image.altText: The Olympic rings pictured in front of the IOC headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland.

items.synopsis: Victoria hardly had to beat rival contenders for the now-dumped 2026 Commonwealth Games, a far cry from the prize fight bidding war for the coveted Olympics. It begs the question — which event is preferable to host?

title.children: Are the Commonwealth Games really so hard to host?

image.altText: A close up shot of Daniel Andrews face during a media conference.

items.synopsis: Given the scepticism over the new Commonwealth Games costings and the outcry from athletes and regional communities, the pressure to release the analysis the Victorian premier is relying on will only build, writes David Speers.

title.children: The $6 billion canary in a cost-of-living crisis: The mystery blowout that sank the Commonwealth Games

image.altText: Education Minister Jason Clare stands at a lectern with a seated audience faced towards him.

items.synopsis: Students and safety advocates say the federal government needs to take immediate and substantial action to curtail sexual violence at universities.

title.children: Students call on federal government to tackle sexual violence at universities

image.altText: NSW police and ambulance cars on a city street at night

items.synopsis: The 43-year-old man was allegedly armed with a knife when he confronted police officers just before midnight.

title.children: NSW police fatally shoot man allegedly armed with knife in Sydney's inner west

image.altText: a vote no pamphlet featuring indigenous artwork

items.synopsis: An indigenous artist and elder is "disgusted" that a painting he composed of Uluru has been reappropriated to help spread misinformation about the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: 'Vote No' to Voice to Parliament flyers peddling false claims under investigation by election watchdog

image.altText: A man standing on a boat with blue water behind him looking at the camera.

items.synopsis: Fishing is all Queensland's Clint Waldon has ever known, but he's worried new regulations banning the use of gillnets will see the end of his business and decimate the industry.

title.children: Clint's family has been fishing for 80 years. He says a new ban on gillnets will destroy the industry

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

items.synopsis: One in five people who test positive for COVID don't get symptoms. This could be explained by a genetic variant and exposure to the common cold, a new study suggests.

title.children: Have you tested positive for COVID but had no symptoms? Scientists find a gene that could explain why

image.altText: A tall brown apartment building

items.synopsis: In 2018, Canada's British Columbia introduced a tax against vacant homes. Three years later, more than 20,000 rentals were back on the market.

title.children: Could a vacancy tax solve Australia's housing crisis? Canada might have the answer

image.altText: Soldiers tend a stationary cannon underneath camouflage netting.

items.synopsis: An Australian man serving on the frontline with the Ukrainian International Legion is alleging that Australians, Ukrainians and other volunteers are being put in danger and threatened with repercussions for speaking out by some incompetent Ukrainian commanders.

title.children: 'It's a meat grinder': Aussie whistleblower claims some Ukrainian Legion commanders are putting soldiers in danger

image.altText: Logos of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.

items.synopsis: Far from improving our lives, a growing body of economic evidence is pointing the finger at big tech as a major factor in economic stagnation and lower wage growth.

title.children: How a 'winner-take-all' tech sector is slowly destroying the global economy

image.altText: A golden logo of a crown made up of dots sits on the side of a blue-tinted glass building.

items.synopsis: Crown's chief financial officer used details of the casino giant's cash-flow woes to argue down a penalty from financial crimes agency AUSTRAC.

title.children: A rare look inside the finances of disgraced casino operator Crown reveals how much it spent wooing 'high-risk' customers

image.altText: Lucas Beattie is among the youngest patients to receive gene therapy for Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

items.synopsis: There's no known cure for the genetic condition Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy but a world-first treatment trial is being hailed as a potential "game changer" for children like Lucas.

title.children: Lucas was facing life in a wheelchair until a medical trial gave his parents hope

image.altText: A serious elderly woman with short grey hair, whtie and grey top, and pink coat in front of old veranda.

items.synopsis: This 89-year-old thought she was getting a "good deal" when a salesman knocked on her door in the late 1960s and offered to install new insulation on her roof. Now she has lung cancer.

title.children: Aileen has been unknowingly living in an asbestos-contaminated house. She fears others may be too

image.altText: A woman on a horse in the outback

items.synopsis: Gabrielle Keating was heading to the bush for a six-week placement. Four years later, she can't imagine living anywhere else and calls on other young doctors to make the move.

title.children: Young doctor loses front teeth but finds love, dream career in outback

image.altText: An elderly woman in a church

items.synopsis: NSW Police allege in court documents Senior Constable Kristian White's decision to deploy his taser on the elderly woman "does not meet the threshold" of acceptable use for officers.

title.children: Officer said 'na bugger it' before tasering 95yo Clare Nowland, court documents allege

image.altText: Athletes are seen before the start of the closing ceremony of the XXI Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast.

items.synopsis: There are less than three years until the 2026 Commonwealth Games are to begin and few cities are capable of stepping in as host.

title.children: From Christchurch to Birmingham, who's in the running for the 2026 Commonwealth Games?
